PULMEI4--G Great Kedica@ Discovery.


1t was stated souc time ago, that an I'M
portant medical discovery had made been Of
an efectual preventa' we and remedy for The
consumption; we are now able to add some
thing on the subject.


This discovery consists in the production
OF new compound substance to which the
name of Pnlmcl has been given, meaning
honey for the lungs, and the effects of which,
OF the human system are to prevent the for
nation of tubercles in the lungs, or to heal
them when formed, as we'll as to remove
gradually all the symptoms Of decline.
The Pulmel is susceptible of being com
bined in a variety of forms, such as choco-
late, syrup, electuary, powders and pills, &c.
lhe most efficient will be the chocolate


which is sweet, grateful all pleasant to the
taste; but as soon as the lungs are affected,


another additional form must then be used,
by inhaing or breathing perfume OF Pull


mel NO deleterious substance enters into it;


none Of the poisonous plants nor Prusslc


aciu, hitherto used by many; but mere active


vegetable substance; and unlike quick med,
iclnes, IT cures the consumption only, anc


nothing else.


The dlscoverer of this new medical SUD


stance, is gentleman OF great medical ant
} botanical knowledge who has been led to j


by many r esearches and experiments upol
!. himself ard others. lie would be inclinet
to publish them at once, for the benefit @
mankind. was it not that the public are S


often ungrateful tobenefactors Even whe
!. patient il taken. the specification may b
obtained and secretly counterfeited. He
, therefore,, Inclined to delay for some year
: the. publici tion of his chemical operation:
PARTICULAR as he will probably be able
t dispose of t lie manipulation to advantage.

From tie PAiiQdekhhia Saturday EVenmg


Past,

Meantime as he does not wish TO be rank.
ed with the uniform dealers in secret rene
dies, he will soon publish Medical DIS
sertation on the different kinds OF Consump-
ton, and their prophylactic cure by the pui-
mel. which shall plainly eyince his knowi-
edge of the subject. while, through modesty,
his name will not even be mentioned, trust
ing altogether to the tried efficiency OF the
Pnlmcl to deserve the attention of patients
and physicians.
In Philadelphia alone, 70oindividuals died
of pulmonary complaints in 1926, out OF
also total deaths, or one in six In 1927
about 800 will die Of the same end as many
in 1928. Out of these large proportion
could be saved every year by the Pulmei;
this is sufficient to deserve trial.


NIEDICUS.

Iurnlps love a light sandy or gravelly soil
or sandy loan. 1t should be made soft
end fine, but not too rich lest the turnips be
rank and i.l-tasted.


Ground that has been newly cleared. Yields
the largest and sweetest tnrpiDs: and on
such spot there is the least danger from in
sects.


Next to new land, swarded ground is to be
chosen for crop of turnips; and the way to
prepare it is to plough it pretty deep in the
spring, and fold it by turning in the stock
for good number Of nights. Tor there is
scarcely any of our fields sufficiently rich to
produce turnips without manuring: and fold
ing hitherto appears to be the best method
of enrching the ground for this purpose
1t should be we'll narrowed as often as
once week, while the folding is contnu-
ed, to mix the excrements cf the cattle with
the soil


The ground should be cross ploughed as
soon as the soil is sufficiently rotten, and re-
duced by narrowing to a fine tilth, before
1t is sowed. Where a good stock is kept
as much as an acre may be sufficiently fold.
ed.


The time for sowing the seed is about the
middle of July. Doing it on a set dey is ri
diculous: for time should be chosen wher
the ground has the right degree of moisture
to make the seed yegetate; and if this shouls
happen a week earlier, or fortnight

We have another prime horror. with
which to regalc our readers-and would to
heaven the details of the transaction were
matter of question. But alas for human
nature, they are established by the decision
Of court Of justice, and of the truth OF the
story, there can be no possible doubt We
heard the particulars some time since, from
a highly respectable and meritorlous oth-
Ger of the United States Navy, who was at
the time on the coast of Cuba, and we have
now before us letter confirming the story
of our friend, from another gentleman OF the
Navy, who was in Havana at the time the aft
far transpired. From our recolections Of
the statement OF our friend, as well as from
the letter, we shall present to our readers a
briet account Of the heart sckenin5 story.


In the summer Of 1921, several Of the cit
liens Of Havana, missed many Of their little
negro children, and the impression was gen
eral that they had been kidnapped, and
sent to the interior. The attention of the
police was called to the subject. bnt the VI
gill nce of the constituted authorities was not
able TO effect discovery.


A little negro girl was sent by her mis-
tress to a cook shop, at which were sold
meat, pies, sausages, &c. remarkable for
tntlr HcHCAEY. nc slloIS udu hO " wal W shS
city 1T was patron lcd by all classes Of pen-
plc-froni the governor down TO the soldier.


fhe alarm was given on finding the little
girl did not return in due tlne-she was
traced to the shop alluded to--and some
gentlemen who hal seen her enter tleposed
that she had not come out. guard was
ordered 20 search the shop, and hopes were
.,ntritai0ed that nest Of kidnappers was a
bout to be discovered In searching the
honse, a trap door was found through which
tie party descended into long and gloomy
vault. strcwed with human bones. In this
Subterranean Golgotha, miserable old ne
gre WAS discovered chained to q post, and
employed in chopping with clcayers the
flesh Of the unfortunate girl, preparatory q
It's being served up in the pastry, which had
acquired for the shop 50 distinguished rep
ntatian The old man stated that he had
been confined, aud thus employed for three
Years. IN which time many ut his fellow crea-
lures had passed through his hands. Inc
shop keepers were immediately arrested,
tried, and four Of them exeCuted.--a fifth
being condemned 10 perpetual lmprison.
ment.

The Saratoga (N. W Sentinel makes The
following among other remark, On the propos-
cd nnvrntion at Harrisburg for tic benefit ot
the Manufacturing interest


The subject /, one of intense interest to the
popNlition OF the United States and one which
should command the attention Of every ndyd-
ua citizen. The depressed state Of our wool
len manufactures, and the ilnpropltlous Influence
Which Il will exert over the other departments
OF industry, have long been the Objects Of seil-
Gus consideration, The almost unbuunded ex-
tent Of territory, aud the fertility OF our SOIL
will give to tine United States reputation among
the nations Of the earth, which has never, litb-
erto been enjoyed by any people. iut to pre-
serve that reputation, and secure to il a durable
and lasting character, our government must feel
Interested in promoting the staple commodities
Of the country. Some means ought TO be adopt
ed TO prevent the consumption offorcign articles,
esnecially where they can be made the natural
products OF our own soil. 10 enjoy the inde-
penelence Of political liberty, and still 10 be de-
pendent on the manufactures OF foreign pow
CT for those materials which may be raised in the
bosom Of our country, IS too huuiliatine


III the growth otwoo, and in the produce OF
bread stiis, the northern section of these states


IS most particul,rll utcresiel; and rs there is 4
great surplus Of home consumption IN the latter,
It becomes the tu'y OF Our inhabitants 10 increase
the de ,nalid for the former. At this period be.
tween 10 and l2,O0O, 900 of dollars are annually
expended n the purchase of European goods,
and for which scarcely am individual article is re
ccved III return The policy which the govern
ments Of Europe have pursued has been such,
that our own manufactures in woollen, especial
| lv, have been almost wholly excluded from ON
markets. The English wool dealers have beer
permitted to pour in food of cloths, and inun
date our emportms Of commerce with those
materials, the moneys to pay for which oreht Il
have been employees in rewar(ling the industry
and exertions Of our own citizens By th
course, the operation of about 10000 Of ou
inhabitants has been seriously injured. The
surplus Of grain, which has, since the termina
ton Of the European wars, been raised in th'
I United States, and which could not be dispose'
of in foreign market, has induced farmers II


direct their attention to the growth of sheep; am
the policy of our government, if not changed


will blight the hopes which have rested upo


the production Of wool.

! have sown them in drills the first week
in August, and had good crop. One great
advantage OF sowing SO late is. that the tur-
nips will escape insects. And if the crop
should not happen to be quite SO large as It
the sowing had been earlier, the roots VIII
not fail OF being better for the table.


One pound of seed is the common allow
ance tor ali acre Of land. But to guard "a
gainst the fly, the quantity may be little
increased. And tits recommended by judi
cious writer's, that it be a mixture OF equal
parts of new and old seeds, that the plants
coming NJ at different times, the one sort
or the other may chance TO escape the 10
sects With this view, Mr.. Tull construct
ed his turnip drill to lodge the seeds at dill
fcrent depths, which it seems hadNshe desir-
ed effect


The seed sown broadcast must be harrow
ed in with short tined harrow, and then
rolled with wooden roller, to break the
clods and level the surface.
In a week, or thereahouts, the young
plants will be up: And if it be dry seascn,
the fly will be apt to destroy them: To pre-
vent which. some powdered soot or lime,
NAV be sowed very thickly over them. by
Sitting, in dewy morning. This will quick
en- the growth of the plants, as well as other
wise defend them. And the faster the plants
grow, the sooner they will unfold Their
rough leaves, and be out of danger OF the
I Hv. Or it may answer we'll to sprinkle the
ground with an infusion OF elder, wormwood,
or tobacco. But it must be done as soon as
the plants are up.


But ifthe young plants cannot be saved, as
It may sometimes 50 happen, the ground may
be narrowed, and sowcd again, the cost OF
seed being but little, to compare with the
loss Of a crop.

bleaching Strazy.--The customary mode

acid, and saturate it with potash until the et-
feryesence subsidies. Dip the straw in the
solution. Again, the oxygenated muriate Of
lime which may be had at any apothecary' 5
shop, dissolved in water, will bleach straw
without the least diminution Of its fltxibllty

1t is stated in the Mechanics Magazine
that the Jews of Modavla and Ukraine, pre-
pare, without any eXpsnce or trouble, and
with common honey, sort of sugar, which
IS solid and white as snow. This they send
to Dantzic, where the distilltrs use it in
making their liquor. The process consists in
exposing the honey to frost. for three weeks,
in some place where neither sun nor snow
can reach it, in vessel which is not con
ductor of caloric. The honey is not con
gealed, but becomes clear and hard like su-
gar.

during which she received the visits Of her
friends. She left Quincy on Friday, accompani-
ed by her son and other members of her family,
made short visit at Prlncetown, and arrived at
Providence on Monday last.

A letter TO the Editors of the Baltimore
merican, from friend at Port au Prince ~
der date of the 5th ult., says.-"The island !,

day"

We have heard the following anccdotc which


places ina strong light the fearless courage Of
the superintendent of the Sing Sing State Pris-
on I'm New-York,) and the salutary awe with
which he has inspired the criminals under his
charge. Having had occasion to nhict some Sc.
we're punishment upon two or three of the con
yicts after they had retired among their fellows,
one OF them was heard to declare in the most so
Tenn manner, and with tremendous oath, that
he "woltla-be the death of the superintendent" )"
whenever fair opportunity offered. This dec
laratien was conveyed TO him by convict who
overheard it. On the following morning, the
superintendent went to the cell of the convict
who had threatened him, carrying in his hand
his shaving utensils. He locked the door. pu,
the key in his pocket, and sitting down, ordered
the convict to shave him. The fellow surprised
at this novel command, proceeded, not withou


tFepldaticn. to perform the task imnosed unor

tits stated that brig of 800 tons has been
purchased by the Hotel keepers at Niagara
Falls. for the purpose OF gratifying the Gu
riosity of their patrons, and the numerous
yisters who assemble at that place. She is
to be decorated i'll splendid manner with all
her canvass spread, and plotel by a French
man into the Rapids above the Horse Shoe.
We learn from an article in the YORK, Up
per Canada, Gazette, that she is to proceed
ON her voyage the latter week of September
and must appear when plonghing through
the foaming rapids and descending the stu
pendous cataract, as magnificent spectacle
as ever man bchcld The pilot is prepar-
ing balloon in which he will ascend from off
the deck upon the brig s entering the rapids.
Was this VOYAGE postponed until June next,
the editor sinks thousands would flock from
Europe to witness it; and if they should, we
have no doubt they would find as great
hoax played oifupon them as was ever prao
tised upon their credulity in the metropolis
Of London.

Mr.. Simeon Brown continues to move
brick houses. &c. Yesterday he commenc-
ed moving large three story brick house,
fortysix feet deep. in Madison street belong
ing to Mr.. Green, which is to be moved 20
feet. This house whose walls are only eight
inches thick, is considered OF more than usu
al Importance, and if successful, may he con-
sidered Mr.. Browns master performance.
There is no doubt of his success. as thus far,
the house has sustained no injury

Curiou$ Fact in .Natural History.
workmen felled large oak in Southwick,
recently, and on cutting it into logs. came
upon cavity in the trunk near the lower
limbs, from which ran out as was judged a
bout one hundred gallons Of water. The
part containing the water was perfectly
sound, above, below aud around, and the
topmost branches were green ADD thrifty
As we have never heard of a similar crcum-
stance, we refer it to the specuaticns OF the
naturalist. -IPesftM Reg,

BY the Eliza, we have received Vera Cruz pa.
pers to the 25th of June.


We find in them no notice Of the Tacubaya
Congress.


An act was passed by the Mexican Congress,
on the Path Of May, to permit, for the period of
t@o years the importation Of lumber, duty free
BY an act OF the 10Th Of SANG month, the Ex
ccutye is authorised to remove ministers and d.
plomatc agents, at its pleasure.


On receipt Of official intelligence Of the death
of the Duke OF York, an act was passed directing
the Mexican civil and military authorities, TO
wear mourning.


The Priest Arenas, accused Of heading a con
spiracy against the Government, WAS executed
on the first OF June. On his way to the place @.
execution, he made some confidential declara
tons to the civil authorities. The brethren OF
his religious order buried him in the convent Of
lacubaya lie did not meet death with firm
ness.


His dead body was exposed to the public
view for m hour, with the label for trsdson 10 NE
eoaatrY The ccclesiastics interceded for his
pardon. Finally they consented to degrade him
from his pries.ly office; but bis Archbishop eA-

III eoay netl9d of remoping Ne taste Of


garlic, or Of tHrnhs from NIX, and thus


1reyentiag i IL batter.


As the dairy is found Of much Importance
20 the agricultural interests 81 this country,
the following is offered to the public through
the medium of your miscellany. The OBJ
ject of the present essay, is to avoid an in
convenience 10 which our dairy is subjected.
and to convert it into an advantage. The
following plan is recommended as method
of removing the garicy taste from mlk,
and producing good sweet butter. i'll place Of
that which is generally considered 50 disa-
sreeabe.


When the milk snew from the COW, pour
one quart Of boiling water into every gallon
of milk; stir It through and put the whole
into broad shallow dishes, So that Il viii not
be above inches deep Let thesedlshcsb be
placed on an open shelf, that the vapou'
may pass freely and entirely away. When
the milk has stoGl ia this manner twelve
hours, it may be put into the churn altogeth-
er, or only the cream, as may be most agree
able TO the taste or practice OF the operator.
Milk from cows that have pasturcd on gar
lie, when managed in ,his way, will Be quite
sweet. Thc plan here proposed is founded
OF analogous experience


The feeding Of CONS on turnips commu-
nicate a disagrceable odour and taste 70 the
milk and butter; but in many parts Of Brit
ain they make excellent butter from turnip
Fed cows, by plan similar to the foregoing,
The bad taste Of the tnrnip consists in some
volatile substance which is eyaporated by
the hotswater. Garlic is much Of the same
nature, but probably more volatile. Biscuit
baked from gallcy flour, has no taste N, gar
lic; but soft bread. or pudding os ii, same
-four, retains il strongly, having both cxpc
:ienced an imperfect evaporation.

y cautiower, leave part on, the sire of a
gooseberry, and all the leaves, second. and
even third heads viii be formed, and thus
ehey may b.. eaten for two or three months
when at present. by cutting the head com
pletely off, the beds Of Caulltiowers arc

above from cotemporary, but with all due
submission to his historical knowledge, We
must say that it stands opposed to our own
experience. The only plan we have found
70 succeed with cauiifiowers, is 70 pull them
up at once, root and branch, anA plant 9th
ers in their stead they do not form separate
heads like ordinary cabbages, at least We
have rever seen them do so--Conco,a Mas

Nagnoha-Near Fish Creek, in Virginia, ten
or twelve miles from the Ohio, there is grove Of
the lofty magnolia, and in the season of flower.
ing, they fill the wilderness with delicious fra
GRANGE for several miles round. The leaves are
more than three feet in length and of proportion.
able width. There arc no other trees of tlis
kind within five hundred miles. 1t has been
stated, that the flowers Of the magnolia in Flor.
da, have been smclt at the distance Of sixty miles.

full articles.headline:
MONUMENT AT WATERLOO.

.ll.xtract Of a I.etter j
full articles.article:
"Whle engaged going over the plains OF
Waterloo, nv attention was often attracted
by most stupendous work going on nen,
horses, and carts, II great nu nbrrs, being
employed; but from the interest felt in tne
details Of the battle, and the guide deacrip
tion, il was some length of time before
could inquire what the building was intend
ed for; at length the opportunity served, and
upon inquiry found it to be monument
which the Government OF the Netherlands
had ordered to be erected on the spot where
the Duke of Wellington, and those who par
took with him in the glory Of t. It GAY.
stood, and where he issued those commauds
which decided that great event. Ih- Dlk"'s
head quarters. at the commencement OF the
engagement, were between two hills, on the
road from BRUISED, IA ChArleroi, behind the
farm OF La Have oaiute; but the French
getting possession " that farm, the Dukt
then moved his htal quarters about two or
three hundred wards q the right, on the ris-
ing ground On whrh this monument is now
Greeting. THIS monument, as it is called,
hss v.rv imposing effect, even in its nn-
hGishel site. II is tn etrthsn mound or
I'LL. 81 4 conical form. resembling the one on
tlt Rath road, n+ar 4 emmett, but Of larger
dimensions, and more striking appearance.
It lsUf iniaeU9e size, being upwards OF seven
hundred fttt diameter at the base, or two
thousand oHe HUNDRED and Sky feet ciroum-
ference. II two hundred feet high, and
one hundred fett il diamets, at the top;
There is daWoie carriage road winding
round il, III srirdl form, and supplying an
easy aeahs of 4 tt, for cdrri.gs s. to tie We.
~ top; aud - TINS road the nHtrrlals have
been, and arc, conveyed to complete the
work. III the centre is shaft OF brick


work, which bas Seen carried np from the
bottom, AID s S'li eoiag on. II is to b. six
\ T. feet higher than the tip ot the eastern
4 m0Uld ,ufaEiug tht whole height two hun
drcd ard sixty feet. Il is intenard for pc
Gcstal, 10 receive lion (Which | understand
is tue crnst Or arms ot Belgium twenty
two feet long, aud twelve feet hleh, which
is ready to be put up when the work is ftn-
ished. The mound has been eighteen months
1 in hand, AND is 10 be oWnleted within SIX
/ more; and from what has already been done


little doubt remains that II Will be SO. For


the first twelve roaths 5000 men, six hun


dred horses, and rs many carts as could be


kept at work, were employed on It, and thc


number has only been reduced as the tcrni-


nation Of this great undertaking approaches


As before mentioned, it is Of ceuical form


with the top cut Off, and out of II the saafl


or pedestal tor the lion rises. A. present, a,


the works are going on at the top, it has I


pleasing appearance, from the grant number
Of horses and carts and people, ascending
and descending BY the winding road. ."-Dem


Press,

full articles.headline:
From tie PAiiQdekhhia Saturday EVenmg


Past,
full articles.article:
PULMEI4--G Great Kedica@ Discovery.


1t was stated souc time ago, that an I'M
portant medical discovery had made been Of
an efectual preventa' we and remedy for The
consumption; we are now able to add some
thing on the subject.


This discovery consists in the production
OF new compound substance to which the
name of Pnlmcl has been given, meaning
honey for the lungs, and the effects of which,
OF the human system are to prevent the for
nation of tubercles in the lungs, or to heal
them when formed, as we'll as to remove
gradually all the symptoms Of decline.
The Pulmel is susceptible of being com
bined in a variety of forms, such as choco-
late, syrup, electuary, powders and pills, &c.
lhe most efficient will be the chocolate


which is sweet, grateful all pleasant to the
taste; but as soon as the lungs are affected,


another additional form must then be used,
by inhaing or breathing perfume OF Pull


mel NO deleterious substance enters into it;


none Of the poisonous plants nor Prusslc


aciu, hitherto used by many; but mere active


vegetable substance; and unlike quick med,
iclnes, IT cures the consumption only, anc


nothing else.


The dlscoverer of this new medical SUD


stance, is gentleman OF great medical ant
} botanical knowledge who has been led to j


by many r esearches and experiments upol
!. himself ard others. lie would be inclinet
to publish them at once, for the benefit @
mankind. was it not that the public are S


often ungrateful tobenefactors Even whe
!. patient il taken. the specification may b
obtained and secretly counterfeited. He
, therefore,, Inclined to delay for some year
: the. publici tion of his chemical operation:
PARTICULAR as he will probably be able
t dispose of t lie manipulation to advantage.

Meantime as he does not wish TO be rank.
ed with the uniform dealers in secret rene
dies, he will soon publish Medical DIS
sertation on the different kinds OF Consump-
ton, and their prophylactic cure by the pui-
mel. which shall plainly eyince his knowi-
edge of the subject. while, through modesty,
his name will not even be mentioned, trust
ing altogether to the tried efficiency OF the
Pnlmcl to deserve the attention of patients
and physicians.
In Philadelphia alone, 70oindividuals died
of pulmonary complaints in 1926, out OF
also total deaths, or one in six In 1927
about 800 will die Of the same end as many
in 1928. Out of these large proportion
could be saved every year by the Pulmei;
this is sufficient to deserve trial.


NIEDICUS.

full articles.headline:
From the n. England Farmer.


TURNIP.S
full articles.article:
Iurnlps love a light sandy or gravelly soil
or sandy loan. 1t should be made soft
end fine, but not too rich lest the turnips be
rank and i.l-tasted.


Ground that has been newly cleared. Yields
the largest and sweetest tnrpiDs: and on
such spot there is the least danger from in
sects.


Next to new land, swarded ground is to be
chosen for crop of turnips; and the way to
prepare it is to plough it pretty deep in the
spring, and fold it by turning in the stock
for good number Of nights. Tor there is
scarcely any of our fields sufficiently rich to
produce turnips without manuring: and fold
ing hitherto appears to be the best method
of enrching the ground for this purpose
1t should be we'll narrowed as often as
once week, while the folding is contnu-
ed, to mix the excrements cf the cattle with
the soil


The ground should be cross ploughed as
soon as the soil is sufficiently rotten, and re-
duced by narrowing to a fine tilth, before
1t is sowed. Where a good stock is kept
as much as an acre may be sufficiently fold.
ed.


The time for sowing the seed is about the
middle of July. Doing it on a set dey is ri
diculous: for time should be chosen wher
the ground has the right degree of moisture
to make the seed yegetate; and if this shouls
happen a week earlier, or fortnight

full articles.headline: From he Frederickabnrg irene.
full articles.article:
We have another prime horror. with
which to regalc our readers-and would to
heaven the details of the transaction were
matter of question. But alas for human
nature, they are established by the decision
Of court Of justice, and of the truth OF the
story, there can be no possible doubt We
heard the particulars some time since, from
a highly respectable and meritorlous oth-
Ger of the United States Navy, who was at
the time on the coast of Cuba, and we have
now before us letter confirming the story
of our friend, from another gentleman OF the
Navy, who was in Havana at the time the aft
far transpired. From our recolections Of
the statement OF our friend, as well as from
the letter, we shall present to our readers a
briet account Of the heart sckenin5 story.


In the summer Of 1921, several Of the cit
liens Of Havana, missed many Of their little
negro children, and the impression was gen
eral that they had been kidnapped, and
sent to the interior. The attention of the
police was called to the subject. bnt the VI
gill nce of the constituted authorities was not
able TO effect discovery.


A little negro girl was sent by her mis-
tress to a cook shop, at which were sold
meat, pies, sausages, &c. remarkable for
tntlr HcHCAEY. nc slloIS udu hO " wal W shS
city 1T was patron lcd by all classes Of pen-
plc-froni the governor down TO the soldier.


fhe alarm was given on finding the little
girl did not return in due tlne-she was
traced to the shop alluded to--and some
gentlemen who hal seen her enter tleposed
that she had not come out. guard was
ordered 20 search the shop, and hopes were
.,ntritai0ed that nest Of kidnappers was a
bout to be discovered In searching the
honse, a trap door was found through which
tie party descended into long and gloomy
vault. strcwed with human bones. In this
Subterranean Golgotha, miserable old ne
gre WAS discovered chained to q post, and
employed in chopping with clcayers the
flesh Of the unfortunate girl, preparatory q
It's being served up in the pastry, which had
acquired for the shop 50 distinguished rep
ntatian The old man stated that he had
been confined, aud thus employed for three
Years. IN which time many ut his fellow crea-
lures had passed through his hands. Inc
shop keepers were immediately arrested,
tried, and four Of them exeCuted.--a fifth
being condemned 10 perpetual lmprison.
ment.

where it has been the custom Of the owners
to receive them with the greatest hospital
ity, until the abuse or too frequent use OF
,his hospitality has rendered these visits less
agreeable than formerly; and consequently
a delicate mind may in some cases prevent
the beneficial effects, which might other
wise result from a voyage to Cuba.


The following table will exhibit the pro-
portion of deaths at Havana, compared
with those of the cities Of New York and
Philadelphia:


Population Deaths.
New-York, in 1926. ending


Dec. 81, 175 SEQ 4273
Philadelphia, $4,000 4i6l
Havana, 10000 3375
But in Havana in 1924. there died 5l22; in
1925, 59el.


What proportion of these were of the SOL
dicrs sent there during those years FROM
spain is nor stated. The opinions and theo-
iies held by many physicians in the Y. States
~ the subject .! inportation of feyers, are
Sitlicuied here.

full articles.headline: MANUFACTURERS.
full articles.article:
The Saratoga (N. W Sentinel makes The
following among other remark, On the propos-
cd nnvrntion at Harrisburg for tic benefit ot
the Manufacturing interest


The subject /, one of intense interest to the
popNlition OF the United States and one which
should command the attention Of every ndyd-
ua citizen. The depressed state Of our wool
len manufactures, and the ilnpropltlous Influence
Which Il will exert over the other departments
OF industry, have long been the Objects Of seil-
Gus consideration, The almost unbuunded ex-
tent Of territory, aud the fertility OF our SOIL
will give to tine United States reputation among
the nations Of the earth, which has never, litb-
erto been enjoyed by any people. iut to pre-
serve that reputation, and secure to il a durable
and lasting character, our government must feel
Interested in promoting the staple commodities
Of the country. Some means ought TO be adopt
ed TO prevent the consumption offorcign articles,
esnecially where they can be made the natural
products OF our own soil. 10 enjoy the inde-
penelence Of political liberty, and still 10 be de-
pendent on the manufactures OF foreign pow
CT for those materials which may be raised in the
bosom Of our country, IS too huuiliatine


III the growth otwoo, and in the produce OF
bread stiis, the northern section of these states


IS most particul,rll utcresiel; and rs there is 4
great surplus Of home consumption IN the latter,
It becomes the tu'y OF Our inhabitants 10 increase
the de ,nalid for the former. At this period be.
tween 10 and l2,O0O, 900 of dollars are annually
expended n the purchase of European goods,
and for which scarcely am individual article is re
ccved III return The policy which the govern
ments Of Europe have pursued has been such,
that our own manufactures in woollen, especial
| lv, have been almost wholly excluded from ON
markets. The English wool dealers have beer
permitted to pour in food of cloths, and inun
date our emportms Of commerce with those
materials, the moneys to pay for which oreht Il
have been employees in rewar(ling the industry
and exertions Of our own citizens By th
course, the operation of about 10000 Of ou
inhabitants has been seriously injured. The
surplus Of grain, which has, since the termina
ton Of the European wars, been raised in th'
I United States, and which could not be dispose'
of in foreign market, has induced farmers II


direct their attention to the growth of sheep; am
the policy of our government, if not changed


will blight the hopes which have rested upo


the production Of wool.

later than the usual time, it need not be re-
GREETED; but the opportunity ought to be em-
braced.


! have sown them in drills the first week
in August, and had good crop. One great
advantage OF sowing SO late is. that the tur-
nips will escape insects. And if the crop
should not happen to be quite SO large as It
the sowing had been earlier, the roots VIII
not fail OF being better for the table.


One pound of seed is the common allow
ance tor ali acre Of land. But to guard "a
gainst the fly, the quantity may be little
increased. And tits recommended by judi
cious writer's, that it be a mixture OF equal
parts of new and old seeds, that the plants
coming NJ at different times, the one sort
or the other may chance TO escape the 10
sects With this view, Mr.. Tull construct
ed his turnip drill to lodge the seeds at dill
fcrent depths, which it seems hadNshe desir-
ed effect


The seed sown broadcast must be harrow
ed in with short tined harrow, and then
rolled with wooden roller, to break the
clods and level the surface.
In a week, or thereahouts, the young
plants will be up: And if it be dry seascn,
the fly will be apt to destroy them: To pre-
vent which. some powdered soot or lime,
NAV be sowed very thickly over them. by
Sitting, in dewy morning. This will quick
en- the growth of the plants, as well as other
wise defend them. And the faster the plants
grow, the sooner they will unfold Their
rough leaves, and be out of danger OF the
I Hv. Or it may answer we'll to sprinkle the
ground with an infusion OF elder, wormwood,
or tobacco. But it must be done as soon as
the plants are up.


But ifthe young plants cannot be saved, as
It may sometimes 50 happen, the ground may
be narrowed, and sowcd again, the cost OF
seed being but little, to compare with the
loss Of a crop.

bleaching Strazy.--The customary mode
OF Bleaching straw for ornamental use. has
been to stove it in case with burning brin-
stone. But there is reader method if ju


diciously applied: take solution of muriatic
acid, and saturate it with potash until the et-
feryesence subsidies. Dip the straw in the
solution. Again, the oxygenated muriate Of
lime which may be had at any apothecary' 5
shop, dissolved in water, will bleach straw
without the least diminution Of its fltxibllty

full articles.headline: INTENIPERANCF
full articles.article:
Few of our citizens have an idea Of the dcplo.
rable extent of drunkenness in this country, or
Of the degeneracy and depravity which it pro-
duces From statement published BY the
managers of the Aims House in Baltimore, it an
pears that OF o23 adults received in that nstit,l-
ton in the year 1926, there were 554 whose pow
erty and misery were the result ofintemperance,
viz.


Debility from intemperance, 2S5; Mania from
drunkenness, Al; Nenereal, every individual of
these being addicted to intemperance, IS; Ul.
GERS, the effect of drunkenness, "a; Fractures
and wounds which were in every case received
whilst the parties were in state Of intoxcation,
28 various diseases, all traced to drunkenness,
l0i crippled whilst the parties were in a state
Of intoSication, S; old age, all habitual drunk
ards, Ssh.

full articles.headline: PROCESS FOR PURIFYING HONEY.
full articles.article:
1t is stated in the Mechanics Magazine
that the Jews of Modavla and Ukraine, pre-
pare, without any eXpsnce or trouble, and
with common honey, sort of sugar, which
IS solid and white as snow. This they send
to Dantzic, where the distilltrs use it in
making their liquor. The process consists in
exposing the honey to frost. for three weeks,
in some place where neither sun nor snow
can reach it, in vessel which is not con
ductor of caloric. The honey is not con
gealed, but becomes clear and hard like su-
gar.

Mrs Adams, the lady of the President, has
lately passed several days in the city of Boston,
during which she received the visits Of her
friends. She left Quincy on Friday, accompani-
ed by her son and other members of her family,
made short visit at Prlncetown, and arrived at
Providence on Monday last.

It did not frghten me, and to let you know sha. a
kind ofa man you have to deal with.n "Na'


Some rude unfeeling boys, not lonp sno.
took dog and threw him into the rapids of,ta'
Niagara river, just above the falls, and the noo, @
animal, in despite Of his exertions, was nrer;n;

A letter TO the Editors of the Baltimore
merican, from friend at Port au Prince ~
der date of the 5th ult., says.-"The island !,
not SO quiet as when was here last. On ,bs
81 INST. four Government Officers were tried
condemned and shot, fora conspiracy TO murder
President Boyer Two more have been arrest
ed, and now await their trial These npoceoJ
ings have caused some alarm among the foreign.
ers, and think the soonerI can leave this H.
better. Yesterday being our Fourth of july the
Americans here, to the amount Of twenty. sat
down to an elegant dinner in celebration of tho
day"

We have heard the following anccdotc which


places ina strong light the fearless courage Of
the superintendent of the Sing Sing State Pris-
on I'm New-York,) and the salutary awe with
which he has inspired the criminals under his
charge. Having had occasion to nhict some Sc.
we're punishment upon two or three of the con
yicts after they had retired among their fellows,
one OF them was heard to declare in the most so
Tenn manner, and with tremendous oath, that
he "woltla-be the death of the superintendent" )"
whenever fair opportunity offered. This dec
laratien was conveyed TO him by convict who
overheard it. On the following morning, the
superintendent went to the cell of the convict
who had threatened him, carrying in his hand
his shaving utensils. He locked the door. pu,
the key in his pocket, and sitting down, ordered
the convict to shave him. The fellow surprised
at this novel command, proceeded, not withou


tFepldaticn. to perform the task imnosed unor

The New Bedford Mercury has good story
Of two friends who attended public dinner
Y. told y. the excellent toast he intended to
give; but ID. contrlved to be called on first, and
gave Ms only toast, and then had him referred to
for a sentiment, when he knew he was man OF
only one idea, and he had stolen that! There's a
situation!

Squirrels.---In consequence of the search
ty OF beach nuts in the woods Of New Hamp-
shire, these quadrupeds have lately sailed
forth to the corn fields of the farmers, and
committed extensive depredations. par
ty Of men turned out with their guns on the
5th ult. and brought home no less than 17t5,
On the 10th the Same party resumed their
sport, and produced Il total OF 1856. Whole
number Killed 67C1.

The Milledgeville Recorder contradcts the
assertion made few days past, that the Hon.
w. II. Crawford had declined the appointment
Of Judge Of the Supreme Court Of Gcorgia-and
says that Mr.. Crawford had accepted the office
and is now the official Judge Of the Northern cir.
cult.

full articles.headline: NIAGARA FALLS.
full articles.article:
tits stated that brig of 800 tons has been
purchased by the Hotel keepers at Niagara
Falls. for the purpose OF gratifying the Gu
riosity of their patrons, and the numerous
yisters who assemble at that place. She is
to be decorated i'll splendid manner with all
her canvass spread, and plotel by a French
man into the Rapids above the Horse Shoe.
We learn from an article in the YORK, Up
per Canada, Gazette, that she is to proceed
ON her voyage the latter week of September
and must appear when plonghing through
the foaming rapids and descending the stu
pendous cataract, as magnificent spectacle
as ever man bchcld The pilot is prepar-
ing balloon in which he will ascend from off
the deck upon the brig s entering the rapids.
Was this VOYAGE postponed until June next,
the editor sinks thousands would flock from
Europe to witness it; and if they should, we
have no doubt they would find as great
hoax played oifupon them as was ever prao
tised upon their credulity in the metropolis
Of London.


YSRera ~ Niagara EaHs.-The York, u.
c. Observer, ofthc 9th inst. gives the fol-
LOWING description OF visters then resident
at Browns spacious and elegant hotel, who
had come to view the Niagara Falls: A
Swiss Colonel, three consols, two OF bona
parte' S Legion of honor; Hamburg, Madras,
Ceylon. Sidney. (N. ). Walesl British Span


sh and Haytien merchants; a Mank's law
vera family from Constahtinople-
tlemen from Berlin, Moscow, Madrid, Ma
dera, and Mata--ive from Ireand-three
from Scotland, and four from England, all
highly pleased with the splendid entertain
mcnts afforded BY the enterprsing proprie-
tor of the Ontario House. lii the piazzas
may be seen at times. exiled monarchs, Re-
publican Generals, European Ambassadors,
Wings. Tories. Radicals, and Royalists, and
naval and military officers of almost every
nation in Europe, who come to view the
mighty and indescribahle works of the God
Of nature displayed at the falls.

Master John Parrish, aged .fttrcn to Miss
Lebius Goodwin. aged sixteen. This is car
rying the advice Of DIR. Franklin to marry
in the morning of lie, to its ultlmatnm. " G
do not know which here to admire most,
the discretion oi the friends, or the tender,
and steadiast love Of the parties themselves.


Fhey seem to have been seized with laud-
able desire 70 people the wild prairies Of IL
nois--CblHM5as JoHrnak

Mr.. Simeon Brown continues to move
brick houses. &c. Yesterday he commenc-
ed moving large three story brick house,
fortysix feet deep. in Madison street belong
ing to Mr.. Green, which is to be moved 20
feet. This house whose walls are only eight
inches thick, is considered OF more than usu
al Importance, and if successful, may he con-
sidered Mr.. Browns master performance.
There is no doubt of his success. as thus far,
the house has sustained no injury

Runa7pay lIascAcs-In Rush county, In
diana, Mr.. Points took the daughter of a
Mr. Young from her fathers house for the

workmen felled large oak in Southwick,
recently, and on cutting it into logs. came
upon cavity in the trunk near the lower
limbs, from which ran out as was judged a
bout one hundred gallons Of water. The
part containing the water was perfectly
sound, above, below aud around, and the
topmost branches were green ADD thrifty
As we have never heard of a similar crcum-
stance, we refer it to the specuaticns OF the
naturalist. -IPesftM Reg,

full articles.headline: MEXICO.
full articles.article:
BY the Eliza, we have received Vera Cruz pa.
pers to the 25th of June.


We find in them no notice Of the Tacubaya
Congress.


An act was passed by the Mexican Congress,
on the Path Of May, to permit, for the period of
t@o years the importation Of lumber, duty free
BY an act OF the 10Th Of SANG month, the Ex
ccutye is authorised to remove ministers and d.
plomatc agents, at its pleasure.


On receipt Of official intelligence Of the death
of the Duke OF York, an act was passed directing
the Mexican civil and military authorities, TO
wear mourning.


The Priest Arenas, accused Of heading a con
spiracy against the Government, WAS executed
on the first OF June. On his way to the place @.
execution, he made some confidential declara
tons to the civil authorities. The brethren OF
his religious order buried him in the convent Of
lacubaya lie did not meet death with firm
ness.


His dead body was exposed to the public
view for m hour, with the label for trsdson 10 NE
eoaatrY The ccclesiastics interceded for his
pardon. Finally they consented to degrade him
from his pries.ly office; but bis Archbishop eA-
cuscd hnselftrom being prcsenta at the ceremony

As the dairy is found Of much Importance
20 the agricultural interests 81 this country,
the following is offered to the public through
the medium of your miscellany. The OBJ
ject of the present essay, is to avoid an in
convenience 10 which our dairy is subjected.
and to convert it into an advantage. The
following plan is recommended as method
of removing the garicy taste from mlk,
and producing good sweet butter. i'll place Of
that which is generally considered 50 disa-
sreeabe.


When the milk snew from the COW, pour
one quart Of boiling water into every gallon
of milk; stir It through and put the whole
into broad shallow dishes, So that Il viii not
be above inches deep Let thesedlshcsb be
placed on an open shelf, that the vapou'
may pass freely and entirely away. When
the milk has stoGl ia this manner twelve
hours, it may be put into the churn altogeth-
er, or only the cream, as may be most agree
able TO the taste or practice OF the operator.
Milk from cows that have pasturcd on gar
lie, when managed in ,his way, will Be quite
sweet. Thc plan here proposed is founded
OF analogous experience


The feeding Of CONS on turnips commu-
nicate a disagrceable odour and taste 70 the
milk and butter; but in many parts Of Brit
ain they make excellent butter from turnip
Fed cows, by plan similar to the foregoing,
The bad taste Of the tnrnip consists in some
volatile substance which is eyaporated by
the hotswater. Garlic is much Of the same
nature, but probably more volatile. Biscuit
baked from gallcy flour, has no taste N, gar
lic; but soft bread. or pudding os ii, same
-four, retains il strongly, having both cxpc
:ienced an imperfect evaporation.

Nagnoha-Near Fish Creek, in Virginia, ten
or twelve miles from the Ohio, there is grove Of
the lofty magnolia, and in the season of flower.
ing, they fill the wilderness with delicious fra
GRANGE for several miles round. The leaves are
more than three feet in length and of proportion.
able width. There arc no other trees of tlis
kind within five hundred miles. 1t has been
stated, that the flowers Of the magnolia in Flor.
da, have been smclt at the distance Of sixty miles.
